text:
Matt: You know what happens when the smog
clears, right?
You see LA.

And that’s where we’re headed on this stop
of the Speaking of Chemistry Road Trip.

We’re checking in on Hosea Nelson, a talented,
early career scientist who’s taking on one

of the longest-standing challenges for chemists:
Learning how to build any molecule nature makes.

Hosea: We are still nowhere close to being
able to make any molecule we want to make
in an efficient and timely manner.

This is a tremendous limitation in developing
pharmaceuticals, for example.

Matt: Hosea’s been attacking this problem
since he was a grad student at CalTech, where

he worked on what’s called total synthesis--not
to be confused with my 80s cover band:
Totally Synthesizers.

Total synthesis is basically chemistry’s
super power.

The goal is to design reactions that start
with simple ingredients and effectively build

more sophisticated products, especially medicines:
antibacterials, antifungals, anti-cancer drugs,
you name it.

Biology is really good at doing this, which
is why a lot of our medicines come from plants,
animals, and bacteria.

About a quarter of all drugs approved in the
U.S. between 1981 and 2014 were made of or derived
from natural products.

But harvesting these molecules from their
natural sources isn’t always practical or
sustainable.

Consider the case of Picato--or ingenol mebutate--a
topical gel that treats a scaly skin condition
that can lead to skin cancer.

Picato’s active ingredient can be created
from ingenol, a molecule that occurs naturally
in plants called spurges.

Here’s the rub: To get 1 g of ingenol, you
need more than 3,000 g of spurge seeds.
That’s part of the reason LEO Pharma, which makes Picato, teamed up
total synthesis superstar, Phil Baran,
and his group at Scripps Research Institute.
They wanted to find a more efficient way to synthesize ingenol.
Long story short, they did it.

Now dig this sweet synthesis developed by
UCLA’s up-and-comer Hosea during his CalTech days.

He totally synthesized molecules known as
transtaganolides, which occur naturally in
Thapsia plants.

These compounds could help combat malaria,
some forms of cancer, and African sleeping

sickness, which is a parasitic disease that affects
the central nervous system.

The irony here is that Thapsia plants themselves are
poisonous.

In fact, people actually call them “deadly
carrots.”

Thanks to Hosea, chemists can now easily get
at the deadly carrot’s potentially therapeutic

ingredients without needing to cultivate poisonous
plants that sound like plot devices from a
really weird children’s book.

Keep in mind, though, it’s not just about
the molecule you end up with, it’s about
how you get there.

It takes a ton of chemical cunning to create
complex medicines from scratch and even more
to do it as efficiently as possible.

As a postdoc, Hosea worked on developing new
catalysts and methods to push reactions along.

When we visited him in the lab that he launched
just last year, he showed us a glowing

example of this, with his work on something
called photocatalysis.

Hosea: These are just chemical reactions that
are going on when you shine light on them

and there’s something called a photocatalyst
in there that takes the light and then uses

the energy of the photons they absorb and
turn it into electrical or chemical energy.

Certainly the inspiration for us, the
kind of reactions we're trying to develop

are going to be useful to people engaged in
total synthesis or in medicinal chemistry.

The end goal is we need the technology to
make any compound we want and quickly so that we
can make better medicines to save lives.

Matt: Huge thanks to Hosea, who, last year,
was one of C&EN’s Talented 12, the dozen

up and coming chemists that you need to know
about.
And guess what!
We just unveiled this year’s class.
Be sure to check them out.

Do you know a chemist that should be in our
Talented 12 next year?

Do us a solid and nominate them by clicking
on the link in the description below.
And be sure to tune into the next episode of the road trip where we talk to Kim Prather of UC
San Diego about bacteria and weather control.
For serious.
